description: A possible temple site, where sample trenching in 1989 uncovered numerous 3rd to 4th century coins and stone relief of a Genius, broken in antiquity. The Genius reportedly stood in an aedicula. A relief of a rider-god was re-used and set into the mill in 1853, judging by the inscription.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Gill Mill, Ducklington (Oxfordshire), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Booth, Simmonds, (2011), Gill Mill, Ducklington and South Leigh, Oxfordshire. Post-excavation assessment and project design, available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1023379
Bagnall-Smith, J., (1995), Interim report on the votive material from Romano-Celtic temple sites in Oxfordshire
